column1: ISLAMABAD U.S. Senator John McCain said on Sunday he would like relations between United States and Pakistan to improve as they have a common enemy in the Islamic State and other radical Islamist groups.Relations between Pakistan and United States have been frayed over the past decade
column2: with U.S. officials frustrated by what they term Islamabad's unwillingness to act against Islamist groups such as the Afghan Taliban and the Haqqani network.Pakistan rejects harboring militants but says there are limits to how much it can do as it is already fighting multiple Islamist groups and is wary of ""blowback"" in the form of more terror attacks on its soil. McCain
column3: visiting Pakistan as part of a U.S. delegation
column4: said he had an ""excellent meeting"" with Pakistani foreign ministry officials.""We come back with a message that we have a common enemy in ISIS
column5: radical Islam and terrorism
column6: and we look forward to closer relations and resolving the differences we have
column7: McCain told Pakistan's national PTV channel.Relations between United States and Pakistan were tested again in May by a U.S. drone strike that killed Afghan Taliban chief Mullah Akhtar Mansour on Pakistani soil.

column1: As part of the visit

column3: the capital of the restive North Waziristan region bordering Afghanistan. column5: Benjamin Sasse and Joe Donnelly - about faltering peace talks to end the civil war in Afghanistan.

By Sharon Bernstein
SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif. - There is no guarantee California will vote to legalize recreational marijuana in November
column3: but political operative and father of four Daniel Conway has already staked his future on it.Conway left his job as chief of staff to Sacramento's celebrity mayor
column4: former Phoenix Suns NBA basketball star Kevin Johnson
column5: to help start the marijuana investment company Truth Enterprises.He is one of hundreds in the most populous U.S. state already pushing ahead with plans to enter a market experts say will be worth $4 billion by 2020.""I'm someone of an age and of a demographic that sees the legalization and normalization of marijuana as inevitable
column6: said Conway
column7: 35. ""This was a chance not just to build companies but to build an industry.""With a population of nearly 40 million people
column8: and a thriving medical marijuana trade legalized 20 years ago
column9: California already has the United States' largest legal marijuana market. Legalization of recreational pot would generate an estimated $1 billion in additional taxes per year.If voters in November approve a measure to legalize and tax marijuana that qualified last Tuesday for the ballot
column10: California would be the fifth U.S. state - and by far the largest - to allow marijuana for recreational use
column14: as well as the District of Columbia.A similar ballot initiative failed in California in 2010
column15: but recent polls show strong support for legalization. The latest effort is backed by mainstream leaders including Lieutenant Governor Gavin Newsom
column16: who helped negotiate the regulations and taxes it would impose.

column1: Eight other states
column2: including Nevada and Maine
column3: also have recreational or medical marijuana proposals headed for their 2016 ballots. California's sheer size as the world's 6th largest economy means a decision by its voters to legalize marijuana could accelerate the trend elsewhere.""I don't believe there will be any precedent in the United States that can compare to it except for maybe the Gold Rush
column4: said Leslie Bocskor
column5: whose Nevada-based private equity firm
column6: Electrum Partners
column7: advises and invests in marijuana-related businesses.The lure of wealth in an uncharted industry is so great that thousands of people are jostling for position

column5: dispensaries
column6: laboratories
column7: law partnerships
column11: she said.Their challenge is to set up an infrastructure for a business that is not yet legal. Conway and his business partner
column14: recently purchased farmland in Northern California that they hope to use to grow marijuana but would not say where before the measure is passed.Newport Beach-based Terra Tech is trying to prepare for recreational sales while building a legal business within the state's medical marijuana marketplace
column15: which has annual sales of $2.7 billion.

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN0ZI0RU	FBI interviews Hillary Clinton in private server probe	"
By Emily Flitter
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK The Federal Bureau of Investigation interviewed Democratic U.S. presidential candidate Hillary Clinton for three and a half hours on Saturday as part of the probe into her use of a private email server while serving as secretary of state
column2: her campaign said.The interview at FBI headquarters in Washington followed a week of intense public focus on the investigation and on  Clinton's viability as a presidential candidate
column3: with four months to go to the election. Her campaign has tried for months to downplay the controversy as a distraction.  In an interview broadcast on MSNBC
column4: Clinton said she was happy to do the FBI interview
column5: which her spokesman earlier described as ""voluntary."" ""I've been answering questions for over a year"" regarding the private email server
column6: Clinton said.It was not clear if the questioning of Clinton signaled an imminent conclusion to the investigation in a pivotal time for the presidential race. It does follow FBI interviews of several of Clinton's former staff members
column7: as well as her top aide Huma Abedin. Clinton is expected to be formally nominated as the Democratic candidate for the Nov. 8 presidential election at the party's convention in less than four weeks. ""Timing of FBI interview
column11: a former senior adviser to President Barack Obama who served as the chief strategist for his two presidential campaigns. ""Best to get it behind her.""Clinton is currently the front-runner for the White House with polls showing her leading presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump.

column1: In a tweet on Saturday
column2: Trump said it was ""impossible for the FBI not to recommend criminal charges against Hillary Clinton. What she did was wrong!""  He also criticized Clinton's husband
column3: former President Bill Clinton
column4: for meeting privately with Attorney General Loretta Lynch earlier this week
column5: which Lynch later said she regretted
column6: though she said they did not discuss the investigation. ""What Bill did was stupid!"" Trump tweeted.The FBI is investigating whether anyone in Clinton's operation broke the law as result of a personal email server kept in her Chappaqua
column7: New York
column8: home while she was secretary of state from 2009 to 2013. One of the questions is whether they mishandled classified information on the server.

column1: Clinton and her staff have struggled to respond to accusations that her use of the server in violation of State Department protocol means she is untrustworthy. Trump has said the investigation should disqualify her from being president.""@HillaryClinton campaign statement says She ""voluntarily"" met w @FBI for 3.5 hours this morning - yeah
column2: lots of people volunteer 2 do that
column3: tweeted the Republican National Committee's communications director
column4: Sean Spicer.WEEK OF TENSIONS

column1: FBI Director James Comey said in testimony to Congress in March he felt pressure to complete the investigation quickly. Adding to the uncertainty over Clinton is the FBI's refusal to say who is the target of its investigation.Republican lawmakers have called for an independent investigation
column2: saying they do not trust the Justice Department to handle the inquiry with impartiality. Republicans
column3: including Trump
column4: intensified their criticism of the process on Thursday after news emerged of Lynch's meeting with Bill Clinton. Lynch said she would accept whatever recommendations the career prosecutors working on the case made about whether to prosecute Clinton.The FBI probe and the partisan fight over the server have added an extra layer of uncertainty to one of the most tumultuous presidential races in recent memory. Trump
column5: a political novice once dismissed by the Republican establishment
column6: will likely emerge this month as the party's nominee and has set his sights on Clinton
column7: who he has labeled ""Crooked Hillary."" Clinton held a nine-point lead over Trump in a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday. (Editing by Mary Milliken)"	['Trump'

By Emily Flitter
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on Saturday tweeted an image of rival Hillary Clinton alongside hundred-dollar bills and a Jewish star bearing the words ""most corrupt candidate ever!""

The original tweet was deleted.Critics said the image featuring the star harkened back to centuries-old anti-Semitic stereotypes
column4: such as the belief that Jews are greedy.

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-north-carolina-lgbt-idUSKCN0ZI05Q	North Carolina lawmakers adjourn after leaving transgender law largely unchanged	"
By Alex Dobuzinskis

North Carolina lawmakers adjourned for the year on Friday night after leaving mostly intact a law restricting transgender bathroom access that has drawn condemnation and jeopardized the state's efforts to host the NBA All-Star Game
column2: officials said.The law passed in March made North Carolina the first U.S. state to require transgender people to use restrooms in public buildings and schools that match the sex on their birth certificate rather than their gender identity.The National Basketball Association has said it could move its All-Star Game out of Charlotte
column3: North Carolina
column4: and has cited concerns over the law's effects on principles of inclusion and equal protection that league officials say they uphold.  A spokesman for the NBA could not immediately be reached for comment.North Carolina state Representative Chris Sgro
column5: a Democrat who opposes the law
column6: which is known as House Bill 2
column7: said he had hoped lawmakers would vote on Friday on whether to repeal it. But they adjourned for the year without holding that vote

column1: It probably means that we're going to have to come back for a special session because we're going to lose the All-Star Game if we don't

column3: who is executive director of the gay rights group Equality North Carolina
column4: said in a phone interview.The NBA All-Star Game is scheduled for February 2017.President Barack Obama
column5: business leaders
column6: entertainers and some prominent politicians have criticized House Bill 2
column7: saying it is unfair to transgender people.

column1: State lawmakers on Friday addressed one point of controversy over House Bill 2 by restoring the right to sue for wrongful termination in state court on allegations of discrimination based on age
column2: sex

column4: officials said. House Bill 2 had removed that right and required such suits to be filed in federal court.The office of Senate Leader Phil Berger
column5: a Republican

column4: an NBA statement said no final decision had yet been made regarding the All-Star Game. (Reporting by Alex Dobuzinskis in Los Angeles; Editing by Nick Macfie)"	[]	['gay']
